question: Which action would most likely slow soil erosion: clearing trees from a hillside or planting trees along cliffs?

content.source_1: Tree roots bind and stabilize soil while canopies reduce raindrop impact and runoff; areas with greater tree cover generally experience lower soil-erosion rates than bare or sparsely vegetated ground.
content.source_2: Planting trees is a human action that increases the number of trees and the extent of tree cover in an area.
content.source_3: When a factor slows a process, increasing that factor will, other things equal, tend to further slow the process; thus increasing soil-stabilizing vegetative cover tends to reduce the rate of erosion.
content.source_4: Tree-planting programs often involve site preparation—removing grasses and shrubs, applying herbicides, and mechanically disturbing or tilling the topsoil—which leaves patches of bare, disturbed soil.
content.source_5: Bare or disturbed soil erodes faster under rainfall than soil protected by continuous ground cover; removing ground cover increases the rate of soil erosion.
content.source_6: Several widely planted forestry species (e.g., pines and eucalypts) can create hydrophobic litter layers and have relatively shallow lateral roots; on sloped sites this can increase surface runoff and exacerbate erosion compared with prior grass/shrub cover.
